entry.title: Interactive Map with Leaflet
entry.summary: Leaflet is the leading open-source JavaScript library for mobile-friendly interactive maps.
entry.content:
Leaflet is the leading open-source JavaScript library for mobile-friendly interactive maps.

We'll draw a interactive map with Leaflet.

entry.title: Support TensorFlow.js
entry.summary: We even support TensorFlow.js in MDX with React.
entry.content:
We even support TensorFlow.js in MDX with React.

Training Data:

  • xs = [1, 3, 6, 10, 15]
  • ys = [1, 5, 11, 19, 29]

Inference result for data 8:

  • Loading...
tip
  • Use inspection tool to see logs of training, such as F12 in Chrome.
  • Refresh the page to see different inference result.

React Function Definition​

http://localhost:3000
import * as tf from '@tensorflow/tfjs';
import {useEffect, useState} from 'react';

export const Predict = ({xsData, ysData, input}) => {
  const [prediction, setPrediction] = useState('Loading...');
  useEffect(() => {
    const runPrediction = async () => {
      const model = tf.sequential();
      model.add(tf.layers.dense({units: 1, inputShape: [1]}));
      model.compile({loss: 'meanSquaredError', optimizer: 'sgd'});
      // Reshape data to 2D for training.
      const xs = tf.tensor2d(xsData, [xsData.length, 1]);
      const ys = tf.tensor2d(ysData, [ysData.length, 1]);
      // Train the model using the data.
      await model.fit(xs, ys, {
        epochs: 10,
        callbacks: {
          onEpochEnd: (epoch, log) => console.log(`Epoch ${epoch}: loss = ${log.loss}`),
        },
      });
      // Use the model to do inference on the provided input.
      const result = model.predict(tf.tensor2d([input], [1, 1]));
      const predictionValue = result.dataSync()[0];
      setPrediction(predictionValue);
    };
    runPrediction();
  }, []); // passing an empty array as the dependency to only trigger once in lifecycle
  return prediction !== undefined ? prediction : 'Loading...';
};

React Function Usage​

http://localhost:3000
<Predict xsData={[1, 3, 6, 10, 15]} ysData={[1, 5, 11, 19, 29]} input={8}></Predict>

entry.title: Support Mermaid Diagrams
entry.summary: Mermaid is a diagramming and charting tool.
entry.content:
Mermaid is a diagramming and charting tool.

See Mermaid Tutorials and play with Mermaid Live Editor.

Sequence Diagram​

Example Mermaid sequence diagram
```mermaid
graph TD;
    A-->B;
    A-->C;
    B-->D;
    C-->D;
```

FlowChart​

Example Mermaid flowchart
```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[Christmas] -->|Get money| B(Go shopping)
    B --> C{Let me think}
    C -->|One| D[Laptop]
    C -->|Two| E[iPhone]
    C -->|Three| F[fa:fa-car Car]
```

entry.title: Support Global Tabs TabItem
entry.summary: Docusaurus provides the `` component that you can use in Markdown thanks to MDX:
entry.content:
Docusaurus provides the <Tabs> component that you can use in Markdown thanks to MDX:

We configured it globally so it's a feature available from everywhere.

entry.title: Support Math KaTeX
entry.summary: Mathematical equations can be rendered using KaTeX.
entry.content:
Mathematical equations can be rendered using KaTeX.

This document only shows usage. for installation, see Docusaurus - Math Equations.

Usage​

Please read KaTeX documentation for more details.

Inline​

Write inline math equations by wrapping LaTeX equations between $:

Let $f\colon[a,b]\to\R$ be Riemann integrable. Let $F\colon[a,b]\to\R$ be
$F(x)=\int_{a}^{x} f(t)\,dt$. Then $F$ is continuous, and at all $x$ such that
$f$ is continuous at $x$, $F$ is differentiable at $x$ with $F'(x)=f(x)$.

Let f ⁣:[a,b]→Rf\colon[a,b] \to \Rf:[a,b]→R be Riemann integrable. Let F ⁣:[a,b]→RF\colon[a,b]\to\RF:[a,b]→R be F(x)=∫axf(t) dtF(x)= \int_{a}^{x} f(t)\,dtF(x)=∫ax​f(t)dt. Then FFF is continuous, and at all xxx such that fff is continuous at xxx, FFF is differentiable at xxx with F′(x)=f(x)F'(x)=f(x)F′(x)=f(x).

Blocks​

For equation block or display mode, use line breaks and $$:

$$
I = \int_0^{2\pi} \sin(x)\,dx
$$
I=∫02πsin⁡(x) dxI = \int_0^{2\pi} \sin(x)\,dxI=∫02π​sin(x)dx

entry.title: MDX Features
entry.summary: Blog posts support Docusaurus Markdown features, such as MDX.
entry.content:
Blog posts support Docusaurus Markdown features, such as MDX.

Interactive​

tip

Use the power of React to create interactive blog posts.

<button onClick={() => alert('button clicked!')}>Click me!</button>

Diagram​

tip

Use the power of React to create diagrams.

import {Chart} from './_asset/snowfall.js';
export const year = 2013;

# Last year’s snowfall

In {year}, the snowfall was above average. It was followed by a warm spring which caused flood conditions in many of the nearby rivers.

<Chart year={year} color="#fcb32c" />;

Last year's snowfall

In 2013, the snowfall was above average. It was followed by a warm spring which caused flood conditions in many of the nearby rivers.

entry.title: Welcome
entry.summary: Docusaurus blogging features are powered by the blog plugin.
entry.content:
Docusaurus blogging features are powered by the blog plugin.

Use a <!-- truncate --> comment to limit blog post size in the list view.

Simply add Markdown files (or folders) to the blog directory.

Regular blog authors can be added to authors.yml.

The blog post date can be extracted from filenames, such as:

  • 2019-05-30-welcome.md
  • 2019-05-30-welcome/index.md

A blog post folder can be convenient to co-locate blog post images:

The blog supports tags as well!

And if you don't want a blog: just delete this directory, and use blog: false in your Docusaurus config.
